name: South by Southwest (SXSW)
description: Massive annual convergence of film, music, and interactive technology that transforms Austin every March.
longDescription: South by Southwest is Austin's most significant cultural event—a multi-week festival that began as a music showcase in 1987 and has grown into a global convergence of film, music, interactive technology, and culture. SXSW draws hundreds of thousands of visitors, fills every venue in the city with performances, and turns Austin into the center of the creative and tech universe. The Interactive portion launches products and ideas, the Film Festival premieres major movies, and the Music Festival showcases thousands of artists across hundreds of venues. For Austin residents, SXSW is both a source of pride and a beloved disruption.
cost: Badge packages from $895+; many free events
tips: Many free events without a badge
history: SXSW began in 1987 as a music festival and has grown into one of the world's most important creative industry events, helping launch careers from Twitter to Billie Eilish.

name: Austin City Limits Music Festival
description: Two-weekend music festival in Zilker Park featuring 130+ acts across 8 stages, Austin's biggest musical event.
longDescription: Austin City Limits Music Festival is one of America's premier music festivals, held across two consecutive three-day weekends in October at Zilker Park. Over 130 musical acts perform across 8 stages, ranging from headlining superstars to emerging local talent. The festival draws over 75,000 daily attendees who enjoy not just music but Austin's famous food trucks, local artisans, and the stunning Zilker Park setting. ACL Fest captures Austin's music culture at its most concentrated and celebrates the city's identity as the Live Music Capital of the World.
tips: Plan your schedule with the app
history: Named after the legendary Austin City Limits TV show, the festival began in 2002 and expanded to two weekends in 2013.

name: Austin Trail of Lights
description: Beloved annual holiday light display in Zilker Park with millions of lights, food vendors, and festive atmosphere.
longDescription: The Austin Trail of Lights is Central Texas's most cherished holiday tradition. Each December, Zilker Park transforms into a magical wonderland of light with over 2 million lights arranged in elaborate displays along a walking trail. Food vendors, live music, and activities create a festive atmosphere. The iconic Zilker Tree—a spiral of lights on the park's moonlight tower—is visible from across the city and has been an Austin tradition since 1967. The event draws hundreds of thousands of visitors and marks the official start of Austin's holiday season.
cost: Free general admission nights; premium nights available
tips: Go on weeknight for smaller crowds
The Zilker Tree is a must-see
history: The Trail of Lights began in 1965 and has grown into one of the largest holiday events in Texas, with the Zilker Tree tradition dating to 1967.

name: Pecan Street Festival
description: Huge biannual arts and crafts festival on historic 6th Street with hundreds of vendors and live music.
longDescription: The Pecan Street Festival is one of the largest arts and crafts festivals in the United States, held biannually on historic 6th Street (originally named Pecan Street). Hundreds of artisan vendors display and sell original works including painting, sculpture, jewelry, pottery, and photography. Three stages feature live music throughout the day, and food vendors serve Austin favorites. The spring and fall events each draw over 200,000 visitors to the historic entertainment district, creating a street-festival atmosphere that celebrates Austin's creative community.
tips: Go early for best art selection

name: Austin Food + Wine Festival
description: Three-day celebration of Austin's culinary scene with celebrity chef demos, tastings, and exclusive dinners.
longDescription: The Austin Food + Wine Festival is a three-day celebration of Austin's extraordinary culinary scene, bringing together the city's best chefs, restaurants, and food artisans alongside national culinary stars. The festival features live cooking demonstrations, wine and spirits tastings, exclusive multi-course dinners, and a grand tasting event along Auditorium Shores. It's the best way to experience the breadth and depth of Austin's food culture in a concentrated, festive format. The festival has helped establish Austin as one of America's premier food cities.
location: Auditorium Shores and various Austin restaurants
tips: Grand tasting is the main event

name: Formula 1 US Grand Prix
description: Formula 1 racing at Circuit of the Americas with world-class racing, concerts, and international spectacle.
longDescription: The Formula 1 United States Grand Prix brings the world's premier motorsport to Austin's Circuit of the Americas (COTA) every October. The state-of-the-art circuit, designed by Hermann Tilke, features challenging elevation changes unique among F1 tracks. Race weekend includes practice sessions, qualifying, support races, and the main event on Sunday. Major musical acts perform post-race concerts. The event draws an international crowd and generates massive economic impact. For Austin residents, the F1 weekend is a world-class sporting event in their backyard.
location: Circuit of the Americas, 9201 Circuit of the Americas Blvd
cost: General admission from $150+; grandstand seats higher

name: Bat Fest
description: Annual celebration of Austin's famous Congress Avenue Bridge bat colony with live music, food, and bat watching.
longDescription: Bat Fest celebrates Austin's most unusual claim to fame—the 1.5 million Mexican free-tailed bats that live under the Congress Avenue Bridge. This annual August street festival features live music on two stages, over 50 arts and crafts vendors, a bat costume contest, and food from Austin's best vendors. The highlight is the mass bat emergence at dusk, when the colony streams out in a spectacular natural display viewed by thousands of festival attendees lining the bridge and lakefront.
tips: Arrive early for good bat-watching spot

name: Old Settler's Music Festival
description: Four-day Americana and roots music festival in the Hill Country near Austin with camping and community.
longDescription: Old Settler's Music Festival is a four-day celebration of Americana, roots, folk, and bluegrass music held at the Salt Lick Pavilion in Tilmon, just outside Austin in the Hill Country. The festival features multiple stages, workshops, a children's area, and camping that creates a genuine community atmosphere. Unlike the massive commercial festivals, Old Settler's maintains an intimate, family-friendly vibe that celebrates musical traditions. It's a beloved annual pilgrimage for Austin's roots music community.
location: Salt Lick Pavilion, Tilmon TX (near Austin)
cost: Day tickets from $55; camping passes available
tips: Near the famous Salt Lick BBQ

name: Austin Pride
description: Annual LGBTQ+ pride celebration with parade, festival, and events throughout the city.
longDescription: Austin Pride is the city's annual celebration of its vibrant LGBTQ+ community, featuring a colorful parade through downtown, a festival with music and entertainment, and events throughout the week. Austin's reputation as one of the most LGBTQ+-friendly cities in the South makes Pride a significant cultural moment. The parade route winds through downtown, past the Capitol, and draws enthusiastic crowds of supporters. The festival features live music, dancing, vendor markets, and community resources.
tips: Arrive early for good parade spots

name: Republic of Texas Biker Rally (ROT Rally)
description: One of the largest motorcycle rallies in the US with concerts, vendors, and thousands of bikers in Austin.
longDescription: The Republic of Texas (ROT) Biker Rally is one of the largest motorcycle rallies in the United States, bringing hundreds of thousands of motorcycle enthusiasts to Austin each June. The rally features a massive parade of motorcycles through downtown Austin, live concerts by major rock and country acts at Circuit of the Americas, a vendor marketplace with motorcycle gear and accessories, and organized group rides through the scenic Hill Country. The rally is a Texas tradition that celebrates motorcycle culture and freedom.
location: Circuit of the Americas and Downtown Austin
tips: Downtown parade is free to watch

name: Zilker Kite Festival
description: Free annual kite festival in Zilker Park with kite contests, demonstrations, and family fun since 1929.
longDescription: The Zilker Kite Festival is one of Austin's oldest and most charming traditions, dating back to 1929. Each spring, Zilker Park fills with kites of every shape, size, and color in a free, family-friendly celebration that embodies Austin's community spirit. Contests for homemade kites, stunt kite demonstrations, and organized activities make it a full day of entertainment. The open fields of Zilker provide perfect conditions, and the sight of hundreds of kites filling the sky is pure Austin magic.
tips: Bring your own kite or buy one there

name: SFC Farmers' Market at the Triangle
description: Year-round weekly farmers market with local produce, artisan goods, and community gathering.
longDescription: The Sustainable Food Center's Farmers' Market at the Triangle is Austin's premier farmers market, operating year-round every Wednesday and Saturday. Local farmers bring fresh produce, grass-fed meats, artisan cheeses, and baked goods. Artisan vendors sell handmade crafts, prepared foods, and specialty items. The market serves as a community gathering place where Austin's farm-to-table values come to life. The SFC also operates a downtown market on Saturdays at Republic Square.
